qas.question: What was organized to replace the concept of U.S. Volunteers?
When was the National Army demobilized?
Who filled vacancies in the Regular Army?
What was organized to replace the concept of the militias?
When was the National Army started?
What was added to the National Army?

plausible_answers.text: Enlisted Reserve Corps" and "Officer Reserve Corps

qas.question: What were temporary soldiers known as?

context: By the twentieth century, the U.S. Army had mobilized the U.S. Volunteers on four separate occasions during each of the major wars of the nineteenth century. During World War I, <a0_0>the "<b3_0>National Army<b3_0/>"<a0_0/> was organized to fight the conflict, replacing the concept of U.S. Volunteers. It was demobilized at the <a1_0><b4_0>end of World War I<b4_0/><a1_0/>, and was replaced by the <b5_0>Regular Army<b5_0/>, the Organized Reserve Corps, and the State Militias. In the 1920s and 1930s, the "career" soldiers were known as the "<b7_0>Regular Army<b7_0/>" with the <a2_0>"<b6_0>Enlisted Reserve Corps" and "Officer Reserve Corps<b6_0/>"<a2_0/> augmented to fill vacancies when needed.
